The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Cyclic group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a cyclic group involves a group being generated by a single element, which can be described by a surjective group homomorphism from the integers, \\(\textbackslash\textbackslashmathbb{Z}\\), to the group \\(\textbackslash\textbackslashmathcal{G}\\). The definition of a cyclic group does not inherently require the concept of a domain as defined in the context of functions. The domain in the context of a cyclic group refers specifically to the set from which the generating element's powers are derived, which is the set of integers, \\(\textbackslash\textbackslashmathbb{Z}\\). However, this is more about the structure of the group rather than the function's domain as defined in general mathematics. The concept of a domain as the set of all possible input values where the function is defined is not necessary to understand or define a cyclic group. The essential part of understanding a cyclic group is recognizing that it can be generated by the powers of a single element, and this understanding does not depend on the general concept of a domain as used in function theory.
